text.sentence: This report contains excerpts from a group report published earlier today by the Barclays Technology research team entitled Best Ideas Amid a Shaky Market.
We present three ideas to pave the way forward for investors seeking to take advantage of the recent capital markets downdraft Â­ two stocks to OW and one stock to UW or trim .
There will be a day when the investment community feels better about the world, and we think that such a restoration could start to emerge in the near term .
Some stocks could struggle, though, as investors might shy away from self help or cloud challenged companies despite sharply lower valuations.
In the past month, average price to earnings multiples have compressed one.seven
In contrast, while over a longer period, average multiples compressed four.four
turns during the two hundred thousand eight hundred nine global recession when fundamentals were under major duress .
In the next two weeks, quarterly reports of technology companies should support our view that fundamentals are not great, but they are not under major duress like in two thousand eight nine.

Despite IBM's miss on January nineteen, which is more company specific due to the cloud's drag on middleware and services, we think broader tech industry fundamentals are not as bad as the recent compression in valuation metrics would suggest.
While cautious on parts of our dualsector coverage, we do not expect a global recession.

As a result, we think valuation multiple improvements on the order of one two turns could lead the way forward over the next sixty ninety days, particularly on higher quality stories such as Cisco and CDW.
turns in the past month, but we are not expecting the stock's multiple to be an early beneficiary of any near term retracement.
We think that Xerox's operating challenges could give investors pause as the bar stands to rise for self help stories after the recent market pullback and investor unease.
For investors not interested in our three way forward ideas, we provide the latest rendering of our Strength Quadrants to help identify models that could offer above peer or below peer performance.
As highlighted in our October fourteen, two thousand fifteen dual sector launch, our stock ratings and industry views are framed by our Strength Quadrants related to go tomarket and operating model.
Unchanged For a full list of our ratings, price target and earnings changes in this report, please see table on page two.

As a result, investors should be aware that the firm may have a conflict of interest that could affect the objectivity of this report.
Investors should consider this report as only a single factor in making their investment decision.
PLEASE SEE ANALYST CERTIFICATION AND IMPORTANT DISCLOSURES BEGINNING ON PAGE eleven.

The following section is an excerpt from Best Ideas Amid a Shaky Market published by the Barclays Technology research team on twenty two January two thousand sixteen In the past month, average price to earnings multiples have compressed one.seven
In contrast, while over a longer period, average multiples compressed four.four
turns during the two thousand eight nine global recession when fundamentals were under major duress .
In the next two weeks, quarterly reports of technology companies should support our view that fundamentals are not great, but they are not under major duress like in two thousand eight nine.
FIGURE one New Year's two thousand sixteen P/E Compression Shock Wave
Price to earnings based on calendar year two two thousand fifteen Company Avg.
P/E Multiple IT Hardware Apple CDW Hewlett Packard IBM NetApp Xerox Average Networking Arista Brocade Cisco Ffive Juniper Average

Despite IBM's miss on January nineteen, which is more company specific due to the cloud's drag on middleware and services, we think broader tech industry fundamentals are not as bad as the recent compression in valuation metrics would suggest.
While cautious on parts of our dual sector coverage, we do not expect a global recession or a similar valuation compression shock wave of two thousand eight nine.

As a result, we think valuation multiple improvements on the order of one two turns could lead the way forward over the next sixty ninety days, particularly on higher quality stories such as Cisco and CDW.
Barclays | IT Hardware and Data Networking FIGURE two The Big One two thousand eight two thousand nine Global Recession P/E Compression Shock Wave
Price to earnings based on calendar year two two thousand seven two thousand eight two thousand nine Company Avg.
P/E Multiple IT Hardware Apple Hewlett Packard IBM NetApp Xerox Average Networking Brocade Cisco Ffive Juniper Average
In the below figure, we present three select stocks to navigate the recent capital markets downdraft.
Our way forward valuation framework assigns either the pre or postNew Year's two thousand sixteen downdraft multiple to a specific stock.
In the case of CDW and Cisco, we think that as fundamentals are determined not to be under major duress that the predowndraft multiple will be restored in due time.

This approach implies greater than twenty percent appreciation potential in the stock prices of Cisco and CDW in the near term when assuming our EPS estimates remain relatively unchanged and price to earnings multiples return to levels prior to the recent downdraft.
While these two stocks are not our top picks, the implied appreciation potential of both Cisco and CDW is too big to ignore.
FIGURE three THE WAY FORWARD NOT ALL P/E MULTIPLES WILL RETRACE TO PRE two thousand sixteen DOWNDRAFT LEVELS IN THE NEAR TERM

In contrast, there could be instances whereby investors shy away from challenged stories even after any capital markets recovery.
We apply this construct to Xerox, arriving at dollar eight near term stock price implying greater downside to our twelve month price target of dollar nine.
flex its model towards attractive end markets in times of disruption.
consensus estimates, owing to diverse model and U.S. centric revenue exposure.
In addition, E Rate could prop up public sector revenue trends for a few quarters, following the delayed roll out.
segments, such as networking and security, which could prop up gross margin.
While our estimates could have downside risk, we do not think the cuts will take our estimates to current consensus levels, ie, consensus should tick up in coming weeks.
after years of share gains, or the company's ability to flex its portfolio to sturdier tech segments or customer verticals could fade.
CDW currently trades at EV/EBITDA and P/E multiples of seven.sevenx
and ten.threex, versus the stock's one year average of eight.ninex
current macro storm and could be re rated higher if investors rotate out of growthtech investments towards more stable value tech companies.
Further, Cisco is making strides to make its products more cloud friendly Â­ even customizing its systems for strategic customers.
prolonged weakness in China could have indirect impact on Cisco's model, we point out that the country drives less than three percent of Cisco revenue.
cloud adoption accelerates beyond our current assumptions, we believe Cisco could experience lower growth for an extended period.
Within the U.S., in particular, carriers are looking to reduce capex by doing more with less by leveraging more software based capabilities.
Cisco is adapting its portfolio to play to this trend, but it is likely deflationary over time, which could present downside risk to our estimates.
Cisco currently trades at EV/EBITDA and P/E multiples of four.eightx and nine.ninex,
versus the stock's three year average of five.eightx and eleven.twox,
We expect Xerox's services revenue growth and operating margin profiles to exhibit increasing downside risk and would not be surprised to see Xerox cut the segment's growth and margin targets.
Such a downdraft could take the stock and keep its valuation multiples at post New Year's downdraft levels.
However, we are not sure what the activist investor can accomplish given that the company has been a perennial cost cutter and increasingly focused on growing capital allocation in recent years.
Despite the high level of recurring revenue, we think that increasing headwinds in printing stand to hurt the transactional side of the model.
We also are concerned that services could continue to struggle as the company revamps its pricing and development strategies.
support more of a yield play stock profile over the long term.
Xerox currently trades at EV/EBITDA and P/E multiples of five.ninex and nine.sixx,
versus the stock's three year average of six.threex and nine.eightx,

Beyond our way forward ideas for near term, opportunistic investing, we recommend long term investors build, add to, or hold positions in the two OW rated stocks in IT Hardware and any of our OW rated or EW rated Data Networking stocks .
In our view, these six stocks can exhibit less downside risk in tougher times and represent potential lead beneficiaries whenever the global economy improves.
Plus, the respective models and end market exposure of these companies sit on the right side of the long term growth vector of the cloud.

For investors looking to take advantage of the recent capital markets pullback but are not interested in our three way forward ideas, we provide our Strength Quadrants to help identify models that could offer above peer or below peer performance.

As highlighted in our October fourteen, two thousand fifteen dual sector launch, our stock ratings and industry views are framed by our Strength Quadrants related to go to market and operating model .
GTM focuses on cloud displacement risk and market share gain potential, and OM focuses on relative margin protection and Ctwo thousand fourteen sixteenE revenue growth CAGR potential.
It is important to note that each company's strengths are evaluated in relation only to our two coverage universes Â­ not the entire tech sector.

There are technology companies not presented below that could rank higher in one or both leadership quadrants, particularly those driving cloud based or software based workloads and related efficiencies and cost savings for the customer.

Apple Apple Juniper HPQ WD Seagate Xerox Nimble IBM NetApp HPE Cloud Shield Margin Protection Brocade CDW Pure HPE WD NetApp Xerox Nimble Seagate Pure Cisco Ffive IBM Juniper CDW Arista HPQ Brocade Cisco Ffive Arista
For the operating model Strength Quadrant, the other key metric is relative margin protection.

We evaluated the gross margin, EBITDA margin, and operating margin trendlines of all companies, and the trends that were below Ctwo thousand fourteenA or indicating a sharp V shaped snapback, typically pointed to higher risk to numbers, and thus, a lower margin protection profile.

Continuing the theme of the cloud divide, for those companies having lower relative cloud insulation or shields, we attached a higher level of risk to their margin profiles even if not fully reflected in our current estimates.
Again, the starting point is evaluating Ctwo thousand fourteenA versus Ctwo thousand sixteenE.

If the estimated gross margin or EBITDA margin already is lower than the Ctwo thousand fourteenA, then our view is that incremental risks loom if cloud related or macroeconomic related deflationary factors intensify in the next twelve eighteen months.

Guide to the Barclays Fundamental Equity Research Rating System: Our coverage analysts use a relative rating system in which they rate stocks as Overweight, Equal Weight or Underweight relative to other companies covered by the analyst or a team of analysts that are deemed to be in the same industry .
In addition to the stock rating, we provide industry views which rate the outlook for the industry coverage universe as Positive, Neutral or Negative .
A rating system using terms such as buy, hold and sell is not the equivalent of our rating system.
Investors should carefully read the entire research report including the definitions of all ratings and not infer its contents from ratings alone.
Stock Rating Overweight The stock is expected to outperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a twelve month investment horizon.
Equal Weight The stock is expected to perform in line with the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a twelvemonth investment horizon.
Underweight The stock is expected to underperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a twelve month investment horizon.

Rating Suspended The rating and target price have been suspended temporarily due to market events that made coverage impracticable or to comply with applicable regulations and/or firm policies in certain circumstances including where the Investment Bank of Barclays Bank PLC is acting in an advisory capacity in a merger or strategic transaction involving the company.
Neutral industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are steady, neither improving nor deteriorating.
Below is the list of companies that constitute the industry coverage universe: U.S. Data Networking Arista Networks, Inc. Ffive Networks, Inc.

Guide to the Barclays Research Price Target: Each analyst has a single price target on the stocks that they cover.
The price target represents that analyst's expectation of where the stock will trade in the next twelve months.
Upside/downside scenarios, where provided, represent potential upside/potential downside to each analyst's price target over the same twelve month period.
Top Picks: Barclays Equity Research's Top Picks represent the single best alpha generating investment idea within each industry, taken from among the Overweight rated stocks within that industry.
Barclays Equity Research publishes global and regional Top Picks reports every quarter and analysts may also publish intra quarter changes to their Top Picks, as necessary.
While analysts may highlight other Overweight rated stocks in their published research in addition to their Top Pick, there can only be one Top Pick for each industry.
To view the current list of Top Picks, go to the Top Picks page on Barclays Live .
